title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the forested hillside in Northern Manhattan mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It's the only place in New York City with coyotes.

options.label: B
options.text: It's one of the last areas with clean spring water seeping out of the ground.

options.label: C
options.text: It's the largest park in New York City.

options.label: D
options.text: It's the only place in New York City with white-footed mice.

multiple-choice.question: Why are the northern dusky salamanders found only in a few locations in New York City?

options.label: A
options.text: They are an invasive species and were only recently introduced to the city.

options.label: B
options.text: They require a specific type of habitat that is only found in a few locations.

options.label: C
options.text: They were once common in the city but are now only found in a few isolated areas.

options.label: D
options.text: They are extinct in the city.

multiple-choice.question: How are the researchers studying the genetic differences between the white-footed mice in different parks?

options.label: A
options.text: By observing their behavior and physical characteristics.

options.label: B
options.text: By sequencing thousands of genes from the mice and comparing them to genes from country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: By tracking their movements and migrations.

options.label: D
options.text: By studying their diet and habitat.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Manhattan plot" in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To show the distribution of white-footed mice in New York City parks.

options.label: B
options.text: To compare the genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the concept of evolution.

options.label: D
options.text: To show the relationship between gene expression and protein structure.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that the researchers are using the white-footed mouse as a model to understand how species adapt to urban environments?

options.label: A
options.text: By studying their behavior and social interactions.

options.label: B
options.text: By analyzing their genetic differences and how they relate to environmental factors.

options.label: C
options.text: By tracking their population dynamics and migration patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: By comparing their physiology to that of other urban species.

multiple-choice.question: If a single base pair changes in a gene, what can happen to the protein that the gene codes for?

options.label: A
options.text: The protein will become more stable and functional.

options.label: B
options.text: The protein will become less stable and functional.

options.label: C
options.text: The protein will change its shape and structure, which can affect its function.

options.label: D
options.text: The protein will remain unchanged.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the ability of an organism to survive and reproduce in its environment?

options.label: A
options.text: Adaptation

options.label: B
options.text: Evolution

options.label: C
options.text: Fitness

options.label: D
options.text: Mutation

multiple-choice.question: Why might the genes that encode for immune response to disease be more different between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: Because city mice are more likely to encounter diseases due to their high population density.

options.label: B
options.text: Because country mice are more likely to encounter diseases due to their exposure to wildlife.

options.label: C
options.text: Because city mice have a weaker immune system due to their diet.

options.label: D
options.text: Because country mice have a stronger immune system due to their environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the environmental factors that the researchers are studying in relation to the genetic differences between city and country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: Temperature

options.label: B
options.text: Humidity

options.label: C
options.text: Heavy metal contamination

options.label: D
options.text: Light pollution

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To encourage them to become biologists and study evolution.

options.label: B
options.text: To inform them about the latest research on white-footed mice.

options.label: C
options.text: To encourage them to look at their parks in a new way and appreciate the wildlife that lives there.

options.label: D
options.text: To warn them about the dangers of urbanization and its impact on the environment.

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What was Malcolm McLean's occupation during the Great Depression of the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: Truck driver

options.label: B
options.text: Ship captain

options.label: C
options.text: Stevedore

options.label: D
options.text: Businessman

multiple-choice.question: Describe the process of break bulk shipping that Malcolm McLean observed on the docks.

options.label: A
options.text: Containers were lifted onto the ship and unloaded at the destination.

options.label: B
options.text: Goods were packed into containers and shipped without being touched.

options.label: C
options.text: Boxes, bales, and crates were handled piece by piece and loaded onto the ship.

options.label: D
options.text: Ships were loaded and unloaded using automated machinery.

multiple-choice.question: If a company wants to transport a large quantity of electronics from China to the United States, what would be the most efficient way to do so, considering the concept of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: B
options.text: Air transport

options.label: C
options.text: Container shipping

options.label: D
options.text: Trucking

multiple-choice.question: What was the main advantage of Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced labor costs

options.label: B
options.text: Increased cargo capacity

options.label: C
options.text: Time savings in loading and unloading cargo

options.label: D
options.text: Improved cargo security

multiple-choice.question: Analyze the impact of containerization on global trade. What has been the primary result of this innovation?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced international trade due to increased costs

options.label: B
options.text: Increased reliance on domestic production

options.label: C
options.text: A thriving global marketplace with a wide variety of goods

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased economic growth

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization change the way goods are transported around the world?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in international trade.

options.label: B
options.text: It increased the reliance on break bulk shipping.

options.label: C
options.text: It enabled the efficient and cost-effective transportation of goods.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on global trade.

multiple-choice.question: Synthesize the information about Malcolm McLean's life and innovations. What can be inferred about his personality and character?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a cautious and risk-averse individual.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a visionary who was willing to take risks to pursue his ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a talented engineer who focused solely on technical aspects.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a successful businessman who only cared about profits.

multiple-choice.question: Evaluate the significance of Malcolm McLean's contribution to the development of globalization. What would have been the likely outcome if he had not introduced containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: Globalization would have occurred at the same pace.

options.label: B
options.text: Global trade would have been limited by inefficient transportation methods.

options.label: C
options.text: The global economy would have been unaffected.

options.label: D
options.text: Containerization would have been invented by someone else.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of Malcolm McLean's first container ship, which sailed from Port Newark in 1956?

options.label: A
options.text: Ideal X

options.label: B
options.text: Container Pioneer

options.label: C
options.text: Global Trader

options.label: D
options.text: Sea-Land Explorer

multiple-choice.question: What was the approximate time saved by using containerization instead of break bulk shipping, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-2 days

options.label: B
options.text: 1-2 weeks

options.label: C
options.text: 2-4 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: 1-2 months

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe a partnership between two different species, such as bees and flowers?

options.label: A
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: B
options.text: Mutualism

options.label: C
options.text: Commensalism

options.label: D
options.text: Parasitism

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a symbiotic relationship mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Bees and flowers

options.label: B
options.text: Clark's nutcracker and whitebark pine

options.label: C
options.text: Squirrels and grizzlies

options.label: D
options.text: Black bears and trees

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way Clark's nutcrackers store seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They store them in their nests

options.label: B
options.text: They store them in a pouch in their throat

options.label: C
options.text: They store them in underground burrows

options.label: D
options.text: They store them in tree cavities

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember the location of their cached seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their sense of smell

options.label: B
options.text: They use landmarks on the landscape

options.label: C
options.text: They use a mental map

options.label: D
options.text: They don't remember the location

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines?

options.label: A
options.text: The nutcrackers get food, and the pines get nothing

options.label: B
options.text: The pines get replanted, and the nutcrackers get food

options.label: C
options.text: The nutcrackers get shelter, and the pines get protection

options.label: D
options.text: The pines get water, and the nutcrackers get sunlight

multiple-choice.question: How have whitebark pines evolved to suit the Clark's nutcrackers?

options.label: A
options.text: Their branches sweep downwards to make it harder for nutcrackers to access cones

options.label: B
options.text: Their branches sweep upwards with cones at the ends to make it easier for nutcrackers to access cones

options.label: C
options.text: Their trunks have become thicker to provide more shelter for nutcrackers

options.label: D
options.text: Their roots have become deeper to provide more water for nutcrackers

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if Clark's nutcrackers were to disappear from the ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Whitebark pines would become more abundant

options.label: B
options.text: Whitebark pines would become less abundant

options.label: C
options.text: Squirrels would take over the role of replanting whitebark pines

options.label: D
options.text: Grizzlies and black bears would become the primary seed dispersers

multiple-choice.question: How do squirrels contribute to the ecosystem of whitebark pines?

options.label: A
options.text: They replant whitebark pines

options.label: B
options.text: They disperse seeds by burying them in middens

options.label: C
options.text: They protect whitebark pines from grizzlies and black bears

options.label: D
options.text: They compete with Clark's nutcrackers for food

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines has led to co-evolution?

options.label: A
options.text: The development of long, tough beaks in nutcrackers and the upward sweep of whitebark pine branches

options.label: B
options.text: The increase in seed size in whitebark pines and the decrease in beak size in nutcrackers

options.label: C
options.text: The change in seed color in whitebark pines and the change in feather color in nutcrackers

options.label: D
options.text: The increase in tree height in whitebark pines and the decrease in wing size in nutcrackers

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall benefit of the symbiotic relationship between Clark's nutcrackers and whitebark pines?

options.label: A
options.text: It benefits only the nutcrackers

options.label: B
options.text: It benefits only the whitebark pines

options.label: C
options.text: It benefits both species and the ecosystem as a whole

options.label: D
options.text: It has no significant benefits

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Friction

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: He used a lamp and his assistant to measure the delay in the light coming back

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: By using the speed of sound and the distance between two points

options.label: C
options.text: By measuring the circumference of the Earth and using the angle of the sun's shadow

options.label: D
options.text: By using the distance between two points on the Earth's surface and the speed of light

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's talk about science?

options.label: A
options.text: Science is a closed, black box that only experts can understand

options.label: B
options.text: Science is an open field that anyone can explore and contribute to

options.label: C
options.text: Science is only about discovering new facts and theories

options.label: D
options.text: Science is only about confirming existing results

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the story about Eratosthenes and his calculation of the Earth's circumference?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that science is only about discovering new facts and theories

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that science is an open field that anyone can explore and contribute to

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that even with limited technology, people can make significant discoveries

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that only experts can make significant contributions to science

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the audience about science?

options.label: A
options.text: Science is only for experts and is too complex for ordinary people to understand

options.label: B
options.text: Science is an open field that anyone can explore and contribute to, and curiosity can change the world

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Science is only about confirming existing results and not about making new discoveries
